senses.de: To behave according to socially accepted standards or rules.
senses.ex: She felt the need to conform in order to be accepted by her classmates.

Tips.title: Social Pressure
Tips.description: Conform can imply changing behavior to fit in with a group.
Tips.example: Teenagers often feel pressured to conform to their friends' styles.

Tips.title: Negative Connotation
Tips.description: Sometimes, 'conform' suggests a lack of individuality or submission.
Tips.example: Artists are known for refusing to conform to mainstream tastes.

Tips.title: Peer Influence
Tips.description: Conformity is often driven by the influence of peers and social circles.
Tips.example: At the new school, she conformed quickly to make new friends.

senses.de: To match or be similar in form or nature.
senses.ex: Your work should conform to the guidelines set by your boss.

Tips.title: Similarity
Tips.description: 'Conform' indicates a change to achieve similarity with a standard or example.
Tips.example: His behavior slowly conformed to the company's ethical guidelines.

Tips.title: Alignment
Tips.description: Conforming often means aligning with a pre-existing format or system.
Tips.example: The new software conforms to the latest security protocols.

senses.de: To agree or obey a law or regulation.
senses.ex: We must conform to GDPR when handling user data.

Tips.title: Legal Obligation
Tips.description: In legal contexts, 'conform' stresses the necessity to follow regulations.
Tips.example: Companies must conform to new tax laws effective next year.

Tips.title: Compliance
Tips.description: Conforming implies compliance often with formal or bureaucratic requirements.
Tips.example: All our procedures conform to industry-wide best practices.

senses.de: To make similar in form or character.
senses.ex: They tried to conform the new students to the school's traditional values.

Tips.title: Forced Adaptation
Tips.description: To conform can mean to force someone or something to fit a particular mold.
Tips.example: The new policy aimed to conform spending habits to the budget.

Tips.title: Uniformity
Tips.description: Conforming can result in creating uniformity or eliminating differences.
Tips.example: The uniforms were designed to conform students to a single standard.

Accept.wordDefinition:
Accept means to agree to something or to receive something willingly. For example, you might accept an apology from someone who has wronged you.

While both words have to do with agreeing with something, they are used in different contexts. Acceptance is more personal, while conformity is more about following established rules or norms in society.

Adhere.wordDefinition:
Adhere means to stick to or follow a rule, law or belief. It implies a voluntary decision made by an individual.

For example, a person can adhere to a strict diet by following it carefully.

Adhere suggests voluntary commitment while conform implies compliance with mandatory rules or standards.

Comply.wordDefinition:
The difference between comply and conform is that comply means to follow rules or laws, while conform means to adjust to norms or expectations.

For example, a person complies with a law by following it, but they conform to societal expectations by following trends or customs.

Endorse.wordDefinition:
Endorse means to publicly support or approve of something, someone or an idea. It is applicable when we express our approval, support or recommendation for a person, brand, or an idea.

For example, endorsing a political candidate, endorsing a product, endorsing a charity event.

While both terms involve acceptance and support, conform implies an adherence to specified standards or norms while endorse involves showing approval or support for a specific person, product or idea.

Follow.wordDefinition:
Conform means to comply with rules, standards, or expectations. It implies following a set of guidelines or fitting in with a certain group or culture.

Follow means to come after or go behind something/someone. It implies that there is a leader or guide, and one is simply mimicking their actions.

For example, a young child might follow their parent around the house.

Conform is often used when discussing rules, regulations, social norms, or cultural practices. Follow is used more in terms of physical actions or movement.

Obey.wordDefinition:
Obey implies following a specific command or order from an authority figure. For example, a child obeys their parent's instruction to do their homework.

In simpler terms, obey is following a direct order while conform is following a set of guidelines or expectations.

Observe.wordDefinition:
Observe means to notice or pay attention to something. It implies that you are simply being aware of something, without necessarily changing your behavior in response.

For example, you might observe the flight patterns of birds, without trying to change those patterns.

Observe is more general, and can describe a wide range of situations where you are paying attention to something.

Respect.wordDefinition:
Respect, on the other hand, refers to treating others with consideration and understanding their worth and value as individuals.

It involves showing consideration for their feelings, opinions, and beliefs, even if they differ from our own. For example, respecting someone's religious beliefs means not criticizing or making fun of them for it.

Conform refers to fitting into a certain set of expectations or rules, while respect refers to treating others with kindness and acknowledging their value as individuals.
